“For we know not what to pray for as we ought.'’ He goes on to explain this effect of the Holy Spirit by a contrast, in the first member of which, as we have aheady hinted, our weakness is shewn by synecdoche. “ But the Spirit himself intercedeth for us, with sighs unutterable.'' This is the second member of the contrast, wherein is shewn the assistance of the Holy spirit, who helps our weaknesses, which assistance is——‘ his intercession for us 3' which again is illustrated by the adjunct of the manner, he intercedeth—“ with sighs unutterable.’' By this adjunct of the manner of interceding, the apostle would teach us two things. First, he would teach us that the sighs produced by the Holy Spirit of God in the sons of God themselves, often supply the want of utterance and prayer. Secondly, that these sighs of the Holy Spirit are unutterable, and that for two reasons: either be— cause the inward sense of him who sighs surpasses utterance, so that it cannot be expressed in words3 or, because the sighs of the Holy Spirit surpass the sense itself, and, consequently, the utter- ance also, of the individual sighing———as the apostle would intimate in the following verse, when he says, ⁴ that the mean-ing of these
